I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The 13th summit meeting of the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation 
(SAARC), held in November 2005 in Dhaka, has expanded the avenues for energy sector 
regional cooperation among the South Asian countries. The Dhaka Declaration1 reaffirmed the 
previous Islamabad Declaration on energy sector dialogue and cooperation among SAARC 
member states. In view of the improved prospects for energy sector cooperation in South Asia, 
and based on the signed Memorandum of Understanding,2 the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
and the SAARC Secretariat intensified the discussion for cooperation in the energy sector. 
When the SAARC secretary general visited ADB headquarters in late November 2005, ADB 
agreed to provide technical assistance (TA)3 to strengthen energy sector cooperation. The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
2.  SAARC was formed in 1985 by the heads of state or governments of Bangladesh, 
Bhutan, India,  Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka (i) to promote collaboration and mutual 
assistance in economic, social, cultural, technical, and scientific fields; and (ii) to strengthen 
cooperation among the member states in international forums on matters of common interest. 
The SAARC Secretariat is located in Kathmandu, Nepal, and eight sector- or theme-specific 
SAARC  centers  are  distributed  in  the  SAARC  member  states.  Technical  committees  and 
working groups have been established to promote sector-specific cooperation. The 13th SAARC 
summit approved to establish the SAARC Energy Center (SEC) in Islamabad and the Working 
Group  on  Energy  was  established  during  the  12th  summit  to  promote  sector-specific 
cooperation issues. 
 
3.  ADB is mandated by its Charter to foster regional cooperation in the Asia and Pacific 
region and contribute to the acceleration of economic development. ADB has considerable 
experience  in  promoting  subregional  and  regional  cooperation  initiatives,  including  the  (i) 
Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS), (ii) Central Asian Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC), 
(iii) South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC), and (iv) Subregional Economic 
Cooperation  in  South  and  Central  Asia  (SECSCA)  programs.  The  main  lesson  is  that 
subregional  and  regional  cooperation  initiatives  result  in  (i)  better  allocation  and  use  of 
resources through trade liberalization, (ii) better connectivity and knowledge sharing, and (iii) 
creation  of  opportunities  for  an  increased  level  of  productive  investments.  Improved 
understanding  and  trust  through  cooperation  can  also  contribute  to  peace,  stability  and 
enhanced well being in the region.  
 
4.  ADB fielded the Fact-Finding Mission in April 2006 and the Mission had discussions with 
the  SAARC  Secretariat  in  Kathmandu  and  SEC  in  Islamabad.  During  the  Mission,  senior 
officials at the SAARC Secretariat and SEC and the Mission discussed the possible regional 
technical  assistance  (TA)  concept,  rationale,  outcome,  output,  scope,  and  implementation 
arrangements.  The  SAARC  Secretariat  agreed  in  principle  to  the  scope  of  work  and  the 
implementation arrangements of the proposed TA and requested ADB to prepare the TA paper. 
 
                                                 
1 The Dhaka Declaration was signed at the Thirteenth SAARC Summit held on 13 November 2005 in Dhaka, 
Bangladesh.

II.  ISSUES 
5.  India has the largest power system (126,089 megawatts [MW] installed capacity) among 
all SAARC member states. The other member states and their installed capacities are as 
follows: Pakistan (19,540 MW), Bangladesh (4,680 MW), Sri Lanka (2,387 MW), Nepal (480 
MW), Bhutan (468 MW), and Maldives (115 MW). Except in Sri Lanka, percentage of rural 
electrification is less than 50% in all SAARC member states. Often the vast majority of the rural 
poor and other disadvantaged people and groups are deprived of any form of modern energy 
source. Power system losses in Bhutan and Maldives4 are about 9–11%. System losses in all 
other SAARC member states are much higher. For various reasons, energy is not utilized in the 
most efficient way in all SAARC member states.  
 
6.  Most  SAARC  member  states  have  their  own  energy  sector  strategies  and  overall 
development goals. They also have their plans to meet such goals and the energy requirements 
of  their  countries.  For  example,  India  is  currently  promoting  the  most  ambitious  energy 
expansion program in its history. With the Government’s mission of “Power for All by 2012” at 
an affordable cost, 100,000 MW of new generation capacity is envisaged by 2012, which 
represents an approximate doubling of current generation capacity. Pakistan has an equally 
ambitious plan and expects to increase its installed capacity to 162,590 MW by 2030. However, 
all SAARC member states, in particular not only major energy users but also major producers, 
are faced with serious problems of power shortages today. The estimated gap between the 
power supply and demand varies from 15 to 20% at the minimum. Consumers and industries 
suffer due to planned or unplanned load shedding or power shortages.   
 
7.  Issues such as increasing power shortages in SAARC member states, escalating fuel 
prices, poor access to a modern form energy in rural areas, technology transfer, and sharing 
examples of good practice were discussed at various meetings sponsored by SAARC. As a 
remedy,  at  the  recent  Dhaka  Summit,  SAARC  member  countries  agreed  to  establish  the 
SAARC Energy Centre (SEC) in Islamabad to promote the development of energy resources, 
including hydropower and energy trade in the region; to develop renewable and alternative 
energy resources; and to promote energy efficiency and conservation in the region. 
 
8.  Efficient use of energy, including power, gas, and oil, are critical in promoting economic 
and social development. However, the progress of cooperation in the energy sector among 
SAARC member states has so far been limited and slower than cooperation in other sectors. All 
over the world, there are sensitivities over energy security and trade. Nonetheless, opportunities 
are significant for cooperation in the joint development of energy resources in energy-rich 
countries for export to energy-deficient countries within South Asia and neighboring regions. 
The  trading  of  energy  between  countries  in  South  Asia  and  between  South  Asia  and 
neighboring regions is expected to create a win-win situation for the countries concerned. The 
proposed technical assistance could assist the governments, the private sector, and other 
development partners to support harnessing opportunities to promote energy trade and identify 
options for better use of limited energy resources in the SAARC member states.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The  expected  impact  of  the  TA  is  to  create,  together  with  other  interventions,  an 
enabling environment for optimizing the supply of and demand for energy through energy 
cooperation  within  the  region  in all  its  aspects.  It  will promote  better  dialogue  and  higher 
cooperation, and identify mutually beneficial investment options. It will create a sustainable 
framework for developing the capacity of SEC and that of energy sector professionals in the 
region. The TA will comprise three main components: (i) undertaking the SAARC Regional 
Energy Trade Study (SRETS), which will look into the potential for or impact of energy trade 
among SAARC member states; (ii) developing the capacity of SEC; and (iii) providing technical 
and logistical support by ADB. 
 
10.  The overall expected outcome of the TA is the identification of the most appropriate 
energy development and trading opportunities to meet the growing energy demand in SAARC 
member states. The TA will also improve the viability of such development in the energy sector 
projects in the region by increasing awareness about appropriate incentives, technologies, and 
enabling environment.  
 
11.  As  recommended  by  the  SAARC  Working    Group  on  Energy  in  its  draft  terms  of 
reference (Appendix 2), SRETS will cover all possible aspects of energy sources, including 
electricity,  gas,  oil,  coal,  and  alternative  energy  resources.  More  specifically,  SRETS  will 
examine or assess (i) options for, benefits from, and constraints on energy trade in the region, 
covering  demand and supply─both current and projected―for optimal utilization of energy 
resources  for  the  benefit  of  SAARC  member  countries;  (ii)  prevailing  trade  regimes,  the 
regulatory and legal frameworks of the member countries; (iii) international best practices and 
their relevance or applicability to the region; (iv) various technological, financial, and commercial 
options for operationalizing the energy trade projects; and (v) the viability and modalities for 
developing transnational energy lines (electricity, gas, oil, and others) keeping in view the 
broader concept of the Energy Ring (as stated in the Islamabad Declaration).  
  
12.  The SEC capacity-development component will establish a network of energy sector 
professionals in the region, allowing them to share knowledge, resources, and experience. This 
component will cover activities including undertaking policy studies, training, skills development; 
sharing examples of best practices, and study tours. It will also provide opportunities pertaining 
to energy development and trade for the SEC to undertake the Energy Dialogue, stakeholder 
consultation to facilitate various regular activities such as Experts Working Group Meeting. 
Study tours such as visits to the ASEAN Energy Center in Jakarta by about 25 energy sector 
professionals from all SAARC member states would be another activity. This will allow the 
SAARC  energy  professionals  to  learn  lessons  from  the  ASEAN  Energy  Center,  which  is 
considered a well-organized institution.  
 
13.  Networking of SAARC regional energy professionals will have the following benefits: 
(i) effective  sharing  of  information  leading  to  improved  systems  and  processes, 
(ii) harmonization of policies and guidelines and establishment of  examples of best practice and, 
(iii) joint utilization of grant funding for building capacity. The network for the energy sector 
professionals will be a platform for sharing experience among the regional professionals and 
building the capacity to undertake regional development projects in the future. The network will 
also allow discussion and coordination of policy, strategic, and regulatory issues that are of

4   
mutual interest and facilitate the exchange of information through activities such as seminars, 
training, and workshops. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  In general terms, the TA will build on previous works in the area of energy development 
and trade in close coordination with the SAARC Secretariat, SEC, and SAARC member states 
to ensure that all initiatives are sustainable beyond the TA implementation period. Similar 
activities  in  the  region  and  organizations  involved  in  such  activities  will  be  consulted  and 
coordinated to the extent relevant to the TA activities. Key activities will include, among others, 
(i) conducting SRETS, workshops, study tours, and seminars; and (ii) sharing best-practice 
experiences. A number of consultants, recruited as per ADB guidelines, will work closely with 
the SAARC Secretariat, SEC, governments, and ADB.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1.0 million equivalent. The TA will be entirely 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. Details of the cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 3.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The TA will be implemented over an 18-month period beginning in January 2007. ADB 
will  be  the  Executing  Agency  (EA).  Two  of  the  three  components,  namely,  SRETS  and 
developing SEC capacity, will be implemented by the SAARC Secretariat and/or SEC. The 
technical and logistics support component will be undertaken by ADB in close coordination with 
the SAARC Secretariat. 
 
17.  The two components to be implemented by the SAARC Secretariat will be carried out 
under the overall guidance and direction of the SAARC Standing Committee comprising foreign 
secretaries of the SAARC member states. The outline terms of reference for the consulting 
services are in Appendix 4. The SAARC Secretariat will coordinate and communicate with the 
Standing  Committee,  the  governments  concerned,  and  all  stakeholders  involved  in 
implementing the TA, and keep in close touch with ADB. The SAARC Secretariat will also 
consult the SAARC Working Group on Energy and SEC. 
 
18.  The SRETS will be undertaken by a team of consultants selected as an international 
consulting firm with a team leader who has extensive experience in both energy trade issues 
and the region. The consultants may include national energy experts and international energy 
experts to be engaged for 24 and 8 person-months, respectively (total of 32 person-months). 
   
19.  The  SRETS  will  use,  as  inputs,  all  available  information,  studies,  reports  at  ADB, 
SAARC Secretariat, and others. The team leader will prepare an inception report (IR) including 
a  background  paper  and  a  detailed  work  plan  within  1  month  after  acceptance  of  the 
assignment. The IR will be discussed at the intergovernment inception meeting/workshop of 
SAARC member states, which will deliberate on modalities for carrying out the SRETS. The 
meeting/workshop will also be attended by the SAARC Secretariat, SEC, and ADB team. The IR 
will also present the detailed scope and methodology to carry out the SRETS, for discussion 
and final determination at the inception meeting scheduled in February 2007. The methodology 
to carry out SRETS will have intergovernmental scrutiny before its submission to the Standing 
Committee. The inception meeting will provide recommendations and clear direction for the

5
SRETS  to  be  conducted  by  national  and  international  sector  experts.  The  national  sector 
experts  will  prepare  individual  country  assessments.  The  international  sector  experts  will 
analyze the individual country studies and prepare a draft report from regional energy trade 
perspectives  for  discussion  at  the  second  meeting,  and  finalize  the  SRETS  incorporating 
comments. The final report will be submitted to the Standing Committee for approval. 
 
20.  The capacity development programs will be implemented as agreed upon by the SAARC 
Secretariat, SEC, and ADB. This component will require about 16 person-months of national 
energy experts and 8 person-months of regional energy experts.  
 
21.  At ADB, an ADB TA team will be established, comprising staff of the South Asia Country 
Coordination and Regional Cooperation Division, South Asia Energy Division, Nepal Resident 
Mission, Pakistan Resident Mission, and consultants, as well as other ADB divisions and other 
resident  missions  as  appropriate.  The  South  Asia  Country  Coordination  and  Regional 
Cooperation Division will be responsible for overall TA implementation and close coordination 
with the SAARC Secretariat and within ADB, while the South Asia Energy Division will take the 
lead in monitoring and overseeing the SRETS and capacity-development components. 
 
22.  The technical and logistical support component will be undertaken by ADB. A senior 
advisor (international consultant) will be engaged for 6 person-months for quality control of the 
SRETS.  In  addition,  a  regional  cooperation  advisor  and  a  program  analyst  (both  national 
consultants) will each be recruited for 16 person-months. They will be coordinating with the 
SAARC Secretariat, SEC, consultants, and ADB, and will provide logistics services for TA 
implementation  and  other  activities  related  to  cooperation  in  South  Asia.  An  international 
consulting  firm  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  the  quality  and  cost  based  selection 
procedure to undertake the SRETS. The rest of the consultants and experts for the TA will be 
engaged as individuals. All consultants will be selected in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (April 2006, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis 
for  preparing  the  Energy  Sector  Dialogue  and  South  Asian  Association  for  Regional 
Cooperation Energy Center Capacity Development Project, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE OF THE STUDY ON ENERGY TRADE IN THE SAARC 
REGION 
 
 
1.  A sector/fuel (electricity, gas, and oil) study will be carried out on the options for, benefits 
from, and constraints on energy trade in the region, covering demand and supply―both current 
and projected―for optimal utilization of energy resources for the benefit of SAARC member states. 
 
2.  The study will cover the prevailing trade regimes, and the regulatory and legal frameworks 
of the member states. 
 
3.  It will examine the international best practices and their relevance or applicability to the 
region. 
 
4.  It  will  analyze  the  various  technological,  financial,  and  commercial  options  for 
operationalizing the trade or projects. 
 
5.  It will examine the viability of and modalities for developing transnational energy lines 
(electricity, gas, and oil), keeping in mind the broader concept of the Energy Ring.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.  Consultants will be recruited for the three components of the technical assistance (TA): (i) 
the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) Regional Energy Trade Study 
(SRETS); (ii) developing the capacity of SAARC Energy Center (SEC) and (ii) logistics services 
and support. 
 
A.   Regional Energy Trade Study 
 
1.   Objective 
 
2.  The main objective of the SRETS is to prepare an action plan to improve regional dialogue 
and promote energy projects with regional benefits and win-win options. It will facilitate energy 
trade  among  SAARC  member  states.  The  action  plan  will  explore  the  possible  ways  for 
establishing better dialogue among SAARC member states to promote intraregional power trade, 
exchange of technology, sharing of examples of best practices, and better networking among 
energy sector professionals. The SRETS will identify the major physical, institutional–nonphysical 
constraints hindering energy trade among SAARC member states and recommend an integrated 
approach to overcome these constraints and enhance regional dialogue on energy trade.  
 
2.   Scope of the Study 
 
3.  The SRETS will be implemented as a set of activities. First, a national energy sector review 
will be undertaken in each SAARC member states. During this assessment a detailed analysis of 
subregional and regional cooperation options will be given priority among SAARC member states 
as well as neighboring countries. Second, parallel exercises will be carried out for identifying areas 
for which sector reforms are needed. Third, projects that will yield quick and visible impacts will be 
identified. Finally, it is necessary to examine options for undertaking poverty reduction impact 
studies. 
 
4.  An action plan will also be prepared to look into specific proposals for establishing improved 
energy trade links in the region including major transmission hubs, and to develop a time-bound 
investment plan with possible external assistance. In identifying viable options, physical, financial, 
and institutional factors will be assessed with due attention to measures to prevent or minimize 
risks  of  air  pollution,  adverse  environmental  impacts,  resettlement  and  safeguard  matters.  If 
regional cooperation components are required, they could be considered for financing from the 
regional indicative planning figures of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
 
3.   Areas of Focus 
 
5.  To establish reliable, effective, and efficient regional energy trade study among the SAARC 
member states, the SRETS will have to focus on all possible aspects of energy resources including, 
thermal, hydropower, renewable, natural gas, coal and various traditional and alternative energy 
sources. In this regard the study can focus less on energy options that are readily traded in the 
commodity  markets  (e.g.,  oil).  However,  it  is  also  important  to  focus  on  policy  assessment, 
institutional analysis, price and tariff setting, lessons learned, etc. as part of the SRETS.

4.   Scope of Work 
 
6.  The SRETS will be carried out by an international consulting firm with the assistance of a 
team of national sector experts. An inception meeting will be held in February 2007. It will be 
attended by representatives of the SAARC member states, SAARC Secretariat, representatives 
from SEC, energy experts from the region, and the ADB TA team. The inception report with 
detailed scope of work and terms of reference for SRETS will be discussed and agreed upon 
during the inception meeting. The work of national experts and international experts may include, 
but will not be limited to, the following. 
 
a.   Team Leader (2 person-months) 
 
7.  The team leader will be responsible for undertaking the SAARC Regional Energy Dialogue 
Study (SREDS) by supervising and coordinating the work of the consultants as well as by ensuring 
close collaboration with the SAARC Secretariat, SEC, the government of SAARC member states, 
and ADB. The team leader will review the draft reports and suggest revisions to ensure that the 
studies form a consistent report. The team leader will also  prepare an inception report including a 
background paper and a detailed work plan within 1 month after acceptance of the assignment.  
 
8.  The team leader must 
 
(i)  have extended local/regional working knowledge and experience, and familiarity 
with energy issues of the region; 
 
(ii)  have a good understanding of the sensitivities of energy issues in the region; 
 
(iii)  have easy access to data and government officials in the region; 
 
(iv)  be familiar with the traditions and culture of the region; 
 
(v)  be proficient in South Asian languages; and 
 
(vi)  be based in the region. 
 
b.   National Energy Sector Experts (24 person-months) 
 
9.  One national sector expert from each of the seven SAARC member states will be engaged 
for a national energy sector review, based on the terms of reference to be prepared by ADB and 
agreed upon at the inception workshop. The experts will provide total inputs of 24 person-months, 
but their engagement will vary from one country to another depending on each country’s existing or 
planned energy sector development activities that may have subregional and regional impacts..  
 
10.  The national energy sector experts’ responsibilities will include   
 
(i)  working as members of the national TA team to be established in each SAARC 
member state and comprising government officials and sector experts; 
 
(ii)  reviewing the current status of the energy sector and development plans of the 
country concerned, with special attention to ongoing and planned initiatives for 
regional linkages;

12  Appendix 4 
 
 
 
(iii)  identifying  viable  energy  sector  programs  and  projects  enhancing  efficient 
connectivity with other SAARC member states and other countries; 
 
(iv)  reviewing the institutional capacity of the agencies concerned in the country and 
identifying areas where capacity-building activities and reforms are needed; and 
 
(v)  preparing a national energy sector review report, including maps and transmission 
links, with special attention to regional projects. 
 
c.  International Energy Sector Experts (8 person-months) 
11.  Qualified international energy sector experts will be recruited for a total of 8 person-months 
to determine specific proposals for establishing improved links in the region and, as appropriate, 
further elaborate these concepts. The work will include 
 
(i)  reviewing and synthesizing the national energy sector review reports of all SAARC 
member states prepared by the national sector experts, 
 
(ii)  recommending least-cost and environment-friendly energy projects with regional 
impacts, by examining the costs and benefits of implementing specific regional 
projects and programs as well as institutional constraints identified in the national 
energy sector reviews, 
 
(iii)  examining environmental and social safeguards for the ensuing regional projects, 
 
(iv)  finalizing a regional energy trade study with both publicly and privately financed 
options that would be adequate to serve the needs of the SAARC member states, 
and 
 
(v)  identifying ways of formalizing ties among the national energy sector agencies to 
enable planning and implementation of regional activities in the sector. 
 
B.   Capacity  Development  of  the  South  Asian  Association  for  Regional  Cooperation 
Energy Center  
 
1.  Objective 
 
12.  The  SEC  capacity-developing  programs  will  be  implemented  as  agreed  upon  by  the 
SAARC Secretariat, SEC, and ADB. Emphasis will be on the training of trainers in the priority 
sectors or areas included in the Dhaka Declaration. This component will cover several activities 
including undertaking policy studies, training, skills development, sharing best practices, and study 
tours.  It  will  also  provide  SEC  an  opportunity  to  undertake  Energy  Dialogue,  stakeholder 
consultation (including with nongovernment organizations) to facilitate regular activities such as 
experts working group meetings. Study tours such as visits to the ASEAN Energy Center in Jakarta 
by about 25 energy sector professionals from all SAARC member states, SAARC Secretariat, and 
SEC officials will be another activity. This component will require about 16 person-months of 
national energy experts and 8 person-months of regional energy experts.

Appendix 4  13
2.   Scope of Work 
 
a.  Capacity Development Senior Advisor (regional, 8 person-months) 
 
13.  A senior sector advisor will work, on an intermittent basis, as ADB TA team member and 
assist in ensuring the quality of the SRETS. The responsibilities will include  
 
(i)  reviewing the draft national studies of national consultants and the draft regional 
study, and providing comments from an international best-practices point of view; 
and 
 
(ii)  attending the inception and the second workshops as  resource person and ADB TA 
team member, and providing guidance to improve the SRETS. 
 
b.   Capacity  Development  Implementation  Advisor  (national,  16  person-
months) 
 
14.  The TA implementation advisor will be stationed at SEC, Islamabad, and will (i) work as  TA 
team  member  and  assist  SEC  in  effective  and  efficient  TA  implementation  by  liaising  and 
coordinating with the SAARC Secretariat as a focal person, and ensuring the smooth flow of 
documents and communications among all stakeholders involved in building the capacity of SEC; 
(ii) help prepare conferences, workshops, seminars, and meetings for  the TA, in consultation with 
the SAARC Secretariat; (iii) prepare documents and papers related to developing SEC’s capacity, 
as required; (iv) manage the information database related to TA implementation; and (v) participate 
in TA-related missions or conferences, workshops, and meetings, as required. 
 
C.   Logistics Services and Support 
 
1.   Objective 
 
15.  One Regional Cooperation Advisor, one Senior Programs Analyst and one Senior Advisor, 
will be required to help ADB and the SAARC Secretariat to implement the TA efficiently and 
effectively. 
 
2.   Scope of Work 
 
a.   Regional Cooperation Advisor (national, 16 person-months) 
 
16.  A regional cooperation advisor will be stationed at Nepal Resident Mission and will (i) work 
as ADB TA team member and assist ADB in effective and efficient TA implementation by liaising 
and coordinating with the SAARC Secretariat as a focal person, and ensuring the smooth flow of 
documents and communications among all stakeholders involved in TA implementation; (ii) help 
prepare conferences, workshops, seminars, and meetings under the TA, in consultation with the 
SAARC Secretariat; (iii) prepare TA-related documents and papers as required; (iv) manage the 
information database related to TA implementation; and (v) participate in ADB missions, and 
conferences, workshop, and meetings, as required. 
 
b.   Senior Programs Analyst (national, 16 person-months) 
 
77.  A senior programs analyst will be recruited at ADB’s headquarters for 16 person-months to 
(i) prepare a checklist of logistics requirements/assignments and support SRETS capacity-building

and training activities; and arrange at least 3 conferences, workshops, and meetings for the TA; (ii) 
assist ADB staff in TA administration, including budget preparation and liquidation of all individual 
activities under the TA; (iii) prepare and maintain a comprehensive and orderly filing system for the 
TA, and update files regularly; (iv) help ensure the smooth flow of documents and communications 
related  to  TA  implementation;  (v)  assist  the  TA  implementation  advisor  in  managing  the 
implementation database ; (vi) help draft routine communications; and (vii) participate in ADB 
missions, conferences, workshops, seminars, and meetings as required. 
 
c.  Senior Advisor (international/regional, 6 person-months) 
18.  A senior advisor will work, on an intermittent basis, as the main advisor to the entire 
regional activities and the consultants. However, the main focus will  be on the regional energy 
trade  study  component.  The  senior  advisor  will  closely  coordinate  with  ADB  and  SAARC 
Secretariat. The senior advisor will report to ADB and assure the quality of the final outputs of the 
regional energy trade study. The responsibilities will include  
 
(i)  working closely with ADB and SAARC Secretariat and preparing a detailed work 
program, particularly for the regional energy trade study; 
 
(ii)  reviewing the capacity development work of SEC; 
 
(iii)  reviewing all work by the international consultants and ensuring the required quality 
of their outputs; 
 
(iv)  reviewing the draft national studies by national consultants and the draft regional 
study and providing comments from an international best-practices point of view; 
 
(v)  organizing and attending the inception meeting, other meetings, all major workshops 
as a resource person and ADB TA team member; and  
 
(vi)  providing guidance to improve the SRETS.
